metadata.description: The definitive, fully enriched, and documented knowledge base for the Sofi negotiation learning system.

entries.title: Negotiation Fundamentals & BATNA Analysis
entries.summary: Master the foundational concepts of negotiation, from thorough preparation and interest analysis to the critical skill of calculating your BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement).

steps: Prepare open-ended questions to uncover interests.
contentExample.calculation: Offer A: $100K×70% + Offer B: $95K×90% = Weighted BATNA of $85.5K
contentExample.reliabilityNote: Always cross-verify probabilities with market data.

entries.contentReflection: How does knowing your exact BATNA value change the way you communicate during a negotiation?
book_insights: Claiming vs. Creating Value (Ch.1-2, Negotiation Genius)
Package Reservation Value calculation (p.14, Negotiation Genius)

key_quotes.quote: Preparation is key to effective negotiation.
Your goal should be to maximize value, not just reach an agreement.

appIntegration.description: An interactive checklist that guides users through preparation steps, including a built-in BATNA calculator.
appIntegration.codeExample: batnaCalculator.calculate({ offers: [{val:100, prob:0.7}, {val:95, prob:0.9}] }); // Returns: { weightedBatna: 85500, highestOffer: 95000 }

case_studies.title: The Freelancer's Dilemma
case_studies.summary: A freelance designer with two potential projects must calculate their BATNA to decide which project to accept and what their reservation price should be for each.

entries.title: Negotiation Models: Distributive vs. Integrative
entries.summary: Learn to identify and apply the two primary negotiation models: Distributive (win-lose) for claiming value, and Integrative (win-win) for creating it.

contentExample.integrativeApproach: In a vendor contract, offering extended payment terms for a licensing discount, creating value for both.
contentExample.distributiveApproach: In a used car sale, anchoring with a low initial offer to pull the final price down.

entries.contentReflection: Think of a recent negotiation. Was it primarily distributive or integrative? What one action could you have taken to shift it towards a more integrative approach?

appIntegration.description: Simulate outcomes of applying distributive vs. integrative tactics in the same scenario.
appIntegration.codeExample: simulationLoader.run('dist-vs-int-sim'); // Returns: A comparative outcome report.

case_studies.title: The Startup Acquisition
case_studies.summary: A negotiation between a startup and a large corporation. Initially distributive (focused only on price), it becomes integrative when they add issues like stock options, roles for the founders, and brand autonomy.

entries.title: Principled Negotiation Framework
entries.summary: Implement the four core principles of Fisher and Ury's 'Getting to Yes' framework to transform adversarial conflicts into collaborative problem-solving.
corePrinciples: Separate the people from the problem.
entries.contentReflection: Which of the four principles do you find most challenging to apply in high-pressure situations, and why?

appIntegration.description: Test user understanding of the four principles through scenario-based questions.
appIntegration.codeExample: quizEngine.load({id: 'principled-negotiation-quiz'}); // Returns a quiz object with questions.

case_studies.title: The Landlord-Tenant Dispute
case_studies.summary: A tenant wants a pet but the lease forbids it. Instead of arguing positions ('yes pet' vs 'no pet'), they focus on interests (tenant's companionship vs landlord's fear of property damage) and agree on a 'pet deposit' and specific cleaning clauses (objective criteria).

entries.title: Cognitive Biases in Negotiation
entries.summary: Identify and counteract systematic judgment errors that can sabotage your negotiations, from the 'fixed-pie' bias to anchoring effects.

key_quotes.quote: Negotiators often see themselves as more fair, kind, and cooperative than their counterparts.
Our intuition, while powerful, is fundamentally flawed in predictable ways.

appIntegration.description: Helps users identify their potential biases before a negotiation.

case_studies.title: 2004 NHL Lockout
case_studies.summary: A classic example where a fixed-pie bias led to over $1 billion in losses due to reactive devaluation and a failure to find integrative solutions.

entries.title: Advanced Influence & Persuasion Strategies
entries.summary: Deploy a toolkit of proven persuasion techniques, including loss aversion framing, sequential requests, and the power of social proof to ethically guide the negotiation.

tactics.name: Door-in-the-Face
tactics.description: Start with an extreme request likely to be rejected, then make a more reasonable request.
tactics.application: Salary negotiation: Ask for 20% raise, then retreat to 10% + vacation.

tactics.name: Loss Aversion Framing
tactics.description: Frame proposals in terms of what the other party stands to lose.
tactics.application: Car sales: 'You risk losing $3,500 in repair costs without the warranty.'

key_quotes.quote: People are typically more motivated to avoid losses than to accrue equivalent gains.

appIntegration.description: A chat-based simulator to practice influence tactics and receive feedback.

entries.title: Advanced Value Creation Techniques
entries.summary: Move beyond simple compromises by using logrolling, contingency contracts, and issue-bundling to expand the 'pie' for all parties.

key_quotes.quote: The more issues that are on the table, the more likely it is that each party can obtain what it values most.
Negotiation geniuses continue to seek Pareto improvements even after the ink is dry.

appIntegration.description: Helps users score multiple issues to find potential trade-offs.

case_studies.title: Moms.com Licensing Deal
case_studies.summary: A case of value creation where parties traded airing rights against licensing fees.

case_studies.title: Holbrooke's UN Negotiation
case_studies.summary: Resolved a $1B arrears problem by decoupling the size of payments from the timing.

entries.title: Negotiating from a Position of Weakness
entries.summary: Turn disadvantage into an asset. Learn effective strategies for negotiating when you lack power or strong alternatives by leveraging information and building coalitions.
strategies: Don't reveal your BATNA is weak.
Build coalitions with other weak parties.

key_quotes.quote: Don't reveal that your BATNA is weak, but also don't lie about it.
Extreme weakness can sometimes become a source of strength.

case_studies.title: The Single-Offer Job Negotiation
case_studies.summary: A practical example of securing a job offer first and then negotiating non-salary items like start date or a 6-month performance review, leveraging the company's investment in the hiring process.

entries.title: Ethical Frameworks in Negotiation
entries.summary: Navigate ethical dilemmas with a clear framework. This topic covers bounded ethicality, conflicts of interest, and how to build trust without being exploited.

contentExample.scenario: A counterpart seems to be misrepresenting their alternatives. What do you do?
contentExample.response: Instead of accusing them, ask probing questions based on objective criteria. 'Can you help me understand how that offer is structured, as the market rate is typically X?'

entries.contentReflection: What is your personal 'red line' in a negotiation that you would not cross, even if it meant losing the deal?

externalResources.title: Ethical Negotiation: Strategies for Building Trust

appIntegration.description: Presents users with difficult ethical scenarios and asks them to choose a response.

entries.title: Crisis Negotiation & Deadlock Resolution
entries.summary: Acquire advanced tactics for high-stakes situations. Learn to manage irrationality, de-escalate conflict, break deadlocks, and allow counterparts to save face.
de_escalation_techniques: Respond to anger with calm acknowledgment.
Allow a graceful way to back down (face-saving).
Rebuild trust through small, verifiable steps.

key_quotes.quote: Avoiding the humiliation of your counterpart is a critical principle in high-stakes negotiations.
The greatest danger in crises is not irrationality, but miscalculation.

appIntegration.description: A high-pressure simulation where users must de-escalate an angry counterpart in real-time.

case_studies.title: Cuban Missile Crisis
case_studies.summary: A masterclass in crisis management, using private channels and face-saving solutions to avert nuclear war.

entries.title: Technology & AI in Negotiation
entries.summary: Explore how modern technology, particularly Explainable AI (XAI), is being used to support negotiators through data analysis and predictive modeling.

contentExample.userQuery: Why does the AI recommend a 15% concession?
aiExplanation: Language analysis indicates high time pressure.
Historical data shows 87% probability of closing at 12-18% concession.

book_insights: Using predictive models for BATNA probability estimation.

key_quotes.quote: For a negotiation advisory system to be trusted, its recommendations must be explainable. 'Black box' AI is insufficient.

appIntegration.description: A real-time assistant that provides data-driven suggestions.
appIntegration.codeExample: aiAssistant.getRecommendation({ context: '...' }); // Returns: { recommendation: 'Offer 12% concession', confidence: 0.87, reason: 'Counterpart language shows time pressure.' }

entries.title: Negotiation Learning & Assessment
entries.summary: Move from theory to practice. Assess your knowledge and apply concepts through case analysis and tactic application, based on the principle that expertise requires deliberate practice.

question_types.example: Based on the NHL Lockout case, identify the key biases and suggest two strategies to break the deadlock.
When would you use 'Door-in-the-Face' vs. 'Foot-in-the-Door'? Explain your reasoning.

key_quotes.quote: Experience alone does not create expertise. Acknowledging mistakes and engaging in deliberate practice enables growth.

appIntegration.description: An engine that adapts question difficulty and topic based on user performance.

entries.title: Cross-Cultural Negotiation
entries.summary: Develop your cultural intelligence (CQ) by learning to adapt your negotiation approach across different cultural dimensions like communication styles, hierarchy, and time perception.

contentExample.scenario: A U.S. manager negotiating with a Japanese supplier.
adaptations: The U.S. manager should avoid overly direct refusals.
The Japanese supplier may require more time for internal consensus-building (Nemawashi).

entries.contentReflection: Reflect on a time you experienced a cultural misunderstanding. How could a better understanding of cultural dimensions have prevented it?

appIntegration.description: Provides quick tips based on the cultural profiles of the parties.
appIntegration.codeExample: cultureAdvisor.getTips('USA', 'Japan'); // Returns: { tip: 'Avoid direct "no". Use phrases like "That will be very difficult."', dimension: 'Direct vs. Indirect Communication' }

entries.title: Meta-Topic: The Art of Value Creation
entries.summary: This hub connects all concepts related to 'baking a bigger pie'. Value creation is the process of moving beyond a win-lose mindset to find solutions that benefit all parties, often by introducing new issues or trading on different priorities.
entries.contentReflection: What is one question you could ask in your next negotiation to start exploring possibilities for value creation?

case_studies.title: The Joint Venture
case_studies.summary: Two companies wanting to partner discover their core interests differ: one wants market access, the other wants technology. By creating a new entity that leverages both strengths, they create far more value than a simple licensing deal would have.

entries.title: Meta-Topic: Understanding Power Dynamics
entries.summary: This hub connects all concepts related to managing power in negotiation. Power isn't just about authority; it's about leverage, alternatives (BATNA), information, and psychological influence. Understanding these dynamics is key to both claiming and creating value effectively.
entries.contentReflection: Besides having a strong BATNA, what is another source of power you can bring to a negotiation?

_metadata.compat_note: Additive only. Original 'metadata' and all 'entries' preserved exactly; this _metadata aligns with the concert-wide convention.
